choices.text: Placing in flame till it becomes red hot

questions.text: Bacteriological loops used for culture media inoculation are sterilized by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
• Choice Autoclave:
    Autoclaving is an effective sterilization method using steam under pressure at high temperatures, typically used for sterilizing equipment and media that can withstand heat and moisture. However, it is not typically used for bacteriological loops, as they are small and can be easily sterilized using flame.
  • Choice Placing in flame three times:
    This is incorrect because it doesn't guarantee complete sterilization. The loop needs to be placed in the flame until it is red hot, ensuring it reaches a temperature that can kill all bacteria.
  • Choice Placing in flame till it becomes red hot:
    This is the correct method. When a bacteriological loop is placed in a Bunsen burner flame until it becomes red hot, it ensures complete sterilization by effectively killing any microbes that may be present on the loop's surface. This is the most common method used in microbiological labs for sterilizing loops and needles.
  • Choice Microwave:
    Microwaving is not a standard or effective method for sterilizing bacteriological loops. The microwave heats unevenly and may not reach the temperatures necessary for complete sterilization of the loop.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bacteriological loops are used to inoculate microorganisms into culture media, and they need to be sterile to avoid contamination.
  • The proper method for sterilizing bacteriological loops is to heat them in the flame of a Bunsen burner until they become red hot. This ensures that any pathogens or microbes present on the loop are killed.
  • Sterilization by flame is quick and efficient for small instruments like loops and inoculating needles.
  • Other methods like autoclaving or microwaving are not suitable for this purpose due to the nature of the loop and its size.

Additional Points Related to the MCQ:

questions.text: A 20-year-old develops a pustule that progresses quickly to necrotizing fasciitis. Gram-positive cocci in chains were seen on microscopy of the exudate. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
• Choice Streptococcus pyogenes:
    Correct answer. Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) is a well-known cause of necrotizing fasciitis. It is a gram-positive bacterium that appears as cocci in chains under the microscope. This pathogen is often involved in rapidly progressing soft tissue infections like necrotizing fasciitis, which can develop from minor injuries or breaks in the skin. It can lead to life-threatening tissue destruction, which is characteristic of necrotizing fasciitis.
  • Choice Enterococcus faecalis:
    Enterococcus faecalis is a gram-positive cocci that typically forms pairs or short chains. It is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal and urinary tracts but is not typically associated with necrotizing fasciitis. While it can cause infections in immunocompromised patients, its involvement in severe soft tissue infections like necrotizing fasciitis is uncommon.
  • Choice Staphylococcus aureus:
    Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus that can form clusters rather than chains. While it can cause necrotizing fasciitis, the fact that this case showed cocci in chains makes Streptococcus pyogenes the more likely cause. Staphylococcus aureus infections are usually associated with abscess formation and pus-filled lesions, but necrotizing fasciitis due to Staphylococcus aureus typically presents with less rapid progression compared to infections caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Choice Micrococcus:
    Micrococcus is a gram-positive bacterium that typically appears as tetrads or clusters, not chains. It is commonly found in the environment and on the skin but is not typically associated with necrotizing fasciitis or other severe soft tissue infections. Micrococcus is generally considered a non-pathogenic organism in healthy individuals.

Key Takeaways:

  • Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive infection that can result in significant tissue destruction and systemic toxicity. It requires prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram-positive coccus that forms chains, is the most common pathogen responsible for necrotizing fasciitis.
  • The presence of Gram-positive cocci in chains on microscopy of the exudate strongly suggests Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Other potential pathogens in necrotizing fasciitis include Staphylococcus aureus, but the chain formation in microscopy helps differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes as the causative agent.

Additional Points Related to the MCQ:

questions.text: A farmer comes with a wound acquired a couple of weeks back following a blunt trauma from a farming tool. Microscopy of the wound exudate showed weakly acid-fast beaded filamentous rods as shown in this figure. What is the most likely etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
• Choice Nocardia:
    Correct answer. Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast, gram-positive, beaded, filamentous rods that can cause infections following trauma, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. These bacteria often present with chronic infections that are slow to develop, as seen in the farmer's case where a wound from blunt trauma resulted in a chronic infection. Nocardia is commonly associated with cutaneous, pulmonary, and systemic infections. The beaded appearance on microscopy is characteristic of Nocardia.
  • Choice Bacillus anthracis:
    Bacillus anthracis is the causative agent of anthrax, and it can be associated with wounds, particularly in those who handle animals or animal products. However, Bacillus anthracis does not appear as weakly acid-fast beaded filamentous rods. It typically forms large, rectangular spores and has a distinctive appearance in microscopy that is not consistent with the findings in this case.
  • Choice Listeria:
    Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacterium that can cause infections, particularly in pregnant women, newborns, elderly people, and immunocompromised individuals. Listeria is not acid-fast and does not appear as beaded filamentous rods. It is usually found in contaminated food products and can cause septicemia and meningitis, but it is not the likely cause of this wound infection.
  • Choice MTB (Mycobacterium tuberculosis):
    Mycobacterium tuberculosis is an acid-fast bacillus that causes tuberculosis. Although MTB can cause chronic infections, its appearance is usually in the form of straight or slightly curved rods, not filamentous or beaded rods. Additionally, MTB typically infects the lungs, but it can cause disseminated or cutaneous tuberculosis in rare cases, which is not a common presentation after trauma in this setting.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast, filamentous rods that can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals or following trauma, especially when there is exposure to soil or organic matter.
  • The characteristic beaded appearance and weak acid-fastness on microscopy are key to identifying Nocardia.
  • Other potential pathogens, such as Bacillus anthracis, Listeria, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis, have different morphologic and staining characteristics.
  • Cutaneous Nocardia infections often present as chronic abscesses, cellulitis, or mycetomas, sometimes with delayed healing.

Additional Points Related to the MCQ:

questions.text: Which culture medium is used for the isolation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• Choice Muller Hinton agar:
    Muller Hinton agar is a general-purpose medium used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing, particularly for non-fastidious bacteria. While it can be used for testing the susceptibility of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, it is not typically used for its isolation. Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires specialized media that support its slow-growing nature and lipid-rich cell wall.
  • Choice SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar):
    Sabouraud Dextrose Agar is a medium designed for the cultivation of fungi, particularly dermatophytes and yeasts. It is not suitable for the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is a bacterium, not a fungus.
  • Choice Lowenstein-Jensen's medium:
    Correct answer. Lowenstein-Jensen's medium is a specialized solid medium used for the isolation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is enriched with egg yolk and other nutrients that promote the growth of slow-growing organisms like M. tuberculosis. The medium also contains malachite green, which inhibits the growth of other bacteria, allowing the selective isolation of Mycobacterium species. It is commonly used in tuberculosis diagnosis due to its ability to support the growth of M. tuberculosis over extended periods (often 2-6 weeks).
  • Choice MacConkey agar:
    MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium primarily used for the isolation of Gram-negative bacteria, particularly enteric pathogens. It is not suitable for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, as M. tuberculosis is a Gram-positive, slow-growing bacterium that requires a specific culture medium like Lowenstein-Jensen's medium.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires specialized culture media due to its slow growth and unique cell wall structure.
  • Lowenstein-Jensen's medium is the gold standard for isolating M. tuberculosis because it is selective for mycobacteria and supports their growth.
  • Other common bacterial media, such as Muller Hinton agar, SDA, and MacConkey agar, are not effective for isolating Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis on Lowenstein-Jensen's medium can take several weeks, making culture results time-consuming but definitive.

Additional Points Related to the MCQ:

questions.text: Which of the following is a test for carrying out antibiotic sensitivity testing?
questions.solution:
• Choice Camp test:
    The Camp test is used to identify Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) by detecting the production of a hemolysin. It is not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing.
  • Choice E-test:
    Correct answer. The E-test (also known as the Epsilometer test) is a quantitative method used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic. It involves a strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentration placed on an agar plate, and the point where bacterial growth is inhibited helps determine the MIC.
  • Choice Latex agglutination:
    Latex agglutination is a rapid diagnostic method used for the identification of pathogens (such as bacteria or fungi) by detecting antigens or antibodies. It is not used for antibiotic sensitivity testing.
  • Choice Elek's Test:
    The Elek test is used to detect the presence of diphtheria toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing.

Key Takeaways:

  • The E-test is a widely used method for determining the antibiotic sensitivity of microorganisms by evaluating the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).
  • The other tests listed (Camp test, Latex agglutination, Elek's test) are diagnostic tests for identifying pathogens or specific antigens and not for antibiotic sensitivity.

choices.text: a - II, b - I, c - IV, d - III
a - IV, b - III, c - II, d - I
a - III, b -II, c - I, d - IV
a - I, b -IV, c - I, d - IV

questions.text:
Match the disease with the etiological agents:
a. Donovanosis -
b. Oroya fever -
c. Rat bite fever -
d. Pinta -

Etiological Agents:
I. Bartonella bacilliformis
II. Klebsiella granulomatis
III. Treponema carateum
IV. Streptobacillus moniliformis
questions.solution:
• Donovanosis - II. Klebsiella granulomatis:
    Donovanosis (also known as granuloma inguinale) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a bacterium that leads to painless genital ulcers, which can develop into larger tissue masses.
  • Oroya fever - I. Bartonella bacilliformis:
    Oroya fever (also known as Carrion's disease) is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis, which is transmitted by sand flies and leads to acute febrile illness, followed by chronic cutaneous lesions.
  • Rat bite fever - IV. Streptobacillus moniliformis:
    Streptobacillus moniliformis is the causative agent of rat bite fever, which typically results from a rat bite or contact with contaminated rat secretions. The infection presents with fever, rash, and joint pain.
  • Pinta - III. Treponema carateum:
    Treponema carateum is the bacterium responsible for Pinta, a skin infection that primarily affects people in Central and South America, leading to disfiguring skin lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Correct identification of pathogens is essential in diagnosing rare infections such as Donovanosis, Oroya fever, Rat bite fever, and Pinta.
  • Klebsiella granulomatis and Treponema carateum are important causative agents of skin and genital infections, while Bartonella bacilliformis and Streptobacillus moniliformis are associated with systemic and vector-borne infections.

Reference:

  • CDC - Bartonella bacilliformis
  • CDC - Klebsiella granulomatis
  • CDC - Streptobacillus moniliformis
  • CDC - Treponema carateum

questions.text: Which of the following is primarily a waterborne disease?
questions.solution:
• Choice Hepatitis A:
    Correct answer. Hepatitis A is primarily transmitted through contaminated water or food. It is an enteric virus that causes acute liver infection and is common in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Choice Hepatitis B:
    Hepatitis B is transmitted through blood and bodily fluids, not water. It is associated with sexual contact, blood transfusions, or from mother to child during birth.
  • Choice Hepatitis C:
    Hepatitis C is transmitted primarily through blood-to-blood contact, often through sharing needles or unsterilized medical equipment. It is not a waterborne disease.
  • Choice Hepatitis D:
    Hepatitis D requires the presence of Hepatitis B to cause infection. It is transmitted similarly to Hepatitis B, through blood and bodily fluids, not through water.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hepatitis A is a waterborne disease that causes acute hepatitis, especially in regions with inadequate sanitation.
  • Hepatitis B, C, and D are transmitted via blood and bodily fluids, not water.
  • Prevention of Hepatitis A includes vaccination and proper sanitation practices to avoid contamination of food and water.

questions.text:
Which of the following cancers can be prevented by vaccination?
a. Cervical cancer
b. Burkitt lymphoma
c. Merkel cell lymphoma
d. Hepatocellular carcinoma
questions.solution:
• Choice Cervical cancer:
    Correct answer. Cervical cancer is primarily caused by persistent infection with high-risk strains of Human Papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 16 and 18. Vaccination with the HPV vaccine significantly reduces the risk of developing cervical cancer.
  • Choice Burkitt lymphoma:
    Burkitt lymphoma is a type of cancer associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. There is no vaccine for EBV or Burkitt lymphoma.
  • Choice Merkel cell lymphoma:
    Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare form of skin cancer often associated with Merkel cell polyomavirus. There is currently no vaccine for Merkel cell carcinoma.
  • Choice Hepatocellular carcinoma:
    Hepatocellular carcinoma, a type of liver cancer, is commonly caused by chronic infection with Hepatitis B or C. The Hepatitis B vaccine can prevent the infection, reducing the risk of liver cancer.

Key Takeaways:

  • HPV vaccine helps prevent cervical cancer and other cancers caused by HPV, including throat and anal cancers.
  • Hepatitis B vaccine significantly reduces the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma by preventing chronic Hepatitis B infection.
  • Burkitt lymphoma and Merkel cell lymphoma have viral associations but lack preventive vaccines.

questions.text: A gardener who is a resident of the sub-Himalayan belt presents with painless subcutaneous nodules and shallow ulcers on the arm. Axillary lymph nodes are enlarged. Aspirate from the lymph nodes show elongated yeasts which are 3-5 microns. Culture on fungal medium was done. The image of the colony isolated at 22°C, LPCB mount is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which is a dimorphic fungus that is commonly found in soil and plant material. It presents with painless subcutaneous nodules and ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • Choice B. Chromoblastomycosis: This is caused by pigmented fungi that lead to chronic, localized infections with verrucous lesions, usually in the lower extremities. It is not characterized by the typical features of a lymph node aspiration showing elongated yeasts.
  • Choice C. Coccidiomycosis: This fungal infection, caused by Coccidioides species, is endemic to certain areas like the southwestern U.S. and presents with respiratory symptoms. It does not typically cause subcutaneous nodules or lymphadenopathy in this manner.
  • Choice D. Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, it typically presents with pulmonary symptoms and can disseminate, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, but does not present as subcutaneous nodules with lymphadenopathy in the described manner.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus responsible for sporotrichosis.
  • It is associated with gardeners and people handling plant material.
  • Characteristic finding includes painless nodules and ulcerations with possible lymph node enlargement.

Reference:

Wikipedia - Sporothrix schenckii

questions.text: A farmer presents with swelling of the foot. He gives a history of always walking barefoot. On examination there are multiple ulcers/sinuses. Which of the following infections could have been acquired by the farming due to walking barefoot?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Mycetoma: Mycetoma is a chronic, localized fungal or bacterial infection commonly acquired by trauma, especially in individuals who walk barefoot in contaminated soil. It causes swelling, ulcers, and draining sinuses, particularly in tropical regions.
  • Choice B. Coccidioides: Coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley Fever, is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides It primarily affects the lungs, not the skin or foot as described here.
  • Choice C. Aspergillus fumigatus: Aspergillus species cause respiratory infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They do not cause foot infections or ulcers.
  • Choice D. Curvularia: Curvularia species can cause infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, but it does not commonly cause the severe, chronic lesions associated with mycetoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mycetoma is a chronic infection that involves the skin and subcutaneous tissues, often following trauma.
  • It is commonly seen in tropical regions and is linked to barefoot walking in contaminated soil.
  • It can cause deformity and significant tissue damage if untreated.

Reference:

CDC - Mycetoma

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about cryptococcus?
a. Pathogenic species are URI is positive
b. Cryptococcus gatti is associated with bird guano
c. Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis is an AIDS-defining illness
d. Opportunistic infection is seen in AIDS when CD4 counts fall below 500
questions.solution:
• Choice A. a, b, c: This option includes some correct statements. Cryptococcus is an opportunistic pathogen, and Cryptococcus gattii is indeed associated with bird guano. Additionally, extrapulmonary cryptococcosis is considered an AIDS-defining illness.
  • Choice B. a, c: This is correct. The URI positive refers to Cryptococcus's positive reaction on the urease test. Also, it is an AIDS-defining illness, often occurring in patients with low CD4 counts.
  • Choice C. a, b, d: While Cryptococcus gattii is associated with bird guano, opportunistic infections occur when CD4 counts fall below 200, not 500, making this option incorrect.
  • Choice D. a, b, c, d: This is incorrect because the statement about CD4 counts is not accurate; cryptococcosis generally occurs when CD4 counts are below 200.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with AIDS.
  • Cryptococcus gattii is associated with environmental sources, including bird guano.
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis can be an AIDS-defining illness, and it occurs when the immune system is severely compromised.

Reference:

CDC - Cryptococcosis

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with watery diarrhea. On examination, the baby is severely dehydrated. Which is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. E. coli: coli can cause diarrhea, but the watery diarrhea associated with it is usually more severe and often presents with bloody diarrhea (as seen in enterohemorrhagic strains like O157:H7).
  • Choice B. Shigella: Shigella infection also causes diarrhea, but it is typically more associated with blood and mucus in the stool and often presents with fever and cramping.
  • Choice C. Rotavirus: Rotavirus is a common viral cause of gastroenteritis in young children, leading to watery diarrhea and severe dehydration. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in infants.
  • Choice D. Yersinia: Yersinia infections typically cause gastroenteritis, but it does not commonly cause severe dehydration or watery diarrhea in young children.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rotavirus is a major cause of diarrhea in children under five, leading to severe dehydration.
  • Vaccination against rotavirus has significantly reduced the incidence of severe gastroenteritis in many countries.

Reference:

CDC - Rotavirus

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency with complaints of diarrhea for the last 3 days. Now there is blood in urine, and investigations reveal thrombocytopenia. Stool culture would likely isolate:
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Salmonella enteritidis: Salmonella typically causes gastrointestinal illness and can lead to bloody diarrhea, but it is less commonly associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and thrombocytopenia.
  • Choice B. Shigella sonnei: Shigella infections often cause bloody diarrhea, but thrombocytopenia is not a typical feature of Shigella
  • Choice C. coli O157:H7: This strain of E. coli produces Shiga toxin, which can cause hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), resulting in kidney failure, thrombocytopenia, and bloody diarrhea. It is the most likely cause.
  • Choice D. Aeromonas hydrophila: This pathogen can cause gastroenteritis but is not typically associated with thrombocytopenia or HUS.

Key Takeaways:

  • E. coli O157:H7 is a shiga toxin-producing strain of E. coli that can lead to HUS, a serious condition involving thrombocytopenia and kidney failure.
  • HUS is a critical complication of infections caused by coli O157:H7.

Reference:

CDC - E. coli O157:H7

questions.text: A male patient presents with urethritis. It can be caused by all except:
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Trichomonas vaginalis: Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that can cause urethritis in both men and women.
  • Choice B. Gardnerella vaginalis: This bacterium is primarily associated with bacterial vaginosis in women and is not a common cause of urethritis in men.
  • Choice C. Mycoplasma genitalium: Mycoplasma genitalium is a bacteria that can cause urethritis, especially in sexually active individuals.
  • Choice D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the causative agent of gonorrhea, which commonly causes urethritis in men.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gardnerella vaginalis is not typically a cause of urethritis in men, although it is involved in bacterial vaginosis in women.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Mycoplasma genitalium are common causes of urethritis.

Reference:

CDC - Urethritis

choices.text: Massive infection can cause rectal prolapse
Eggs and stools are noninfective and need time in soil to become infective
Asthma-like conditions can be seen following infection

questions.solution:
• Choice A. Massive infection can cause rectal prolapse: This is incorrect. Rectal prolapse is not a common complication of Ascaris Although large numbers of worms can cause intestinal obstruction, rectal prolapse is more commonly associated with other conditions such as chronic constipation.
  • Choice B. Most infections are asymptomatic: This is correct. Ascaris lumbricoides infections are often asymptomatic, especially with low worm burdens.
  • Choice C. Eggs and stools are noninfective and need time in soil to become infective: This is correct. The eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides need time (usually around two weeks) in the soil to mature into their infective stage.
  • Choice D. Asthma-like conditions can be seen following infection: This is correct. The larval migration through the lungs can cause respiratory symptoms, including wheezing and asthma-like conditions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ascaris lumbricoides is a roundworm that can cause intestinal obstruction and lung symptoms due to its migration.
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, and the eggs need time in the soil to become infective.
  • Rectal prolapse is not a typical complication of Ascaris

Reference:

CDC - Ascaris Lumbricoides

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain. On examination, there is a mass palpable in the right hypochondrium. Ultrasound showed a cystic lesion in the liver. Ultrasound-guided aspiration was done, and microscopy of the aspirate is shown. What is the most likely infection?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Taenia solium: Taenia solium causes cysticercosis, which affects the central nervous system and muscles more commonly than the liver.
  • Choice B. Echinococcus granulosus: This is the correct answer. Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid disease, which is characterized by cystic lesions in the liver (and sometimes lungs) due to the formation of cysts.
  • Choice C. Hymenolepis nana: Hymenolepis nana causes intestinal infection and is not associated with cystic liver lesions.
  • Choice D. Taenia saginata: Like Taenia solium, Taenia saginata causes taeniasis but does not form hydatid cysts in the liver.

Key Takeaways:

  • Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid disease, which results in cystic lesions in the liver.
  • Hydatid cysts can be aspirated and examined microscopically to confirm the diagnosis.
  • This disease is often associated with exposure to dogs, as they are the definitive hosts.

Reference:

CDC - Echinococcosis

questions.text: Which of the following when administered to a patient does not impart passive immunity?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. Monoclonal antibody: Monoclonal antibodies are engineered antibodies that provide passive immunity as they are administered directly.
  • Choice B. IgA: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) can be administered as part of passive immunity, especially in the context of mucosal immunity.
  • Choice C. Antitoxin: Antitoxins are antibodies directed against toxins and provide passive immunity.
  • Choice D. Toxoid: Toxoids are inactivated toxins used in vaccines to induce active immunity, not passive immunity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Passive immunity is when antibodies or immunoglobulins are provided directly to an individual.
  • Toxoids are used for vaccination and provide active immunity, not passive immunity.

Reference:

Passive Immunity - National Institute of Health

choices.text: T Cell interaction with antigen-presenting cell
PD1 on T-cell interaction with PD-L1 on antigen-presenting cell

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in the development of the naive T-cell to an activated helper T-cell?
questions.solution:
• Choice A. T Cell interaction with antigen-presenting cell: This is correct. T-cell activation begins with the interaction between T-cells and antigen-presenting cells (APCs).
  • Choice B. Interaction between CD28 and CD28L: This is correct. The interaction between the CD28 receptor on the T-cell and CD28L on the APC provides a co-stimulatory signal required for T-cell activation.
  • Choice C. PD1 on T-cell interaction with PD-L1 on antigen-presenting cell: This is incorrect. The PD1/PD-L1 interaction is inhibitory and serves to regulate the immune response, preventing overactivation and autoimmunity. It is not involved in the activation of naive T-cells.
  • Choice D. Cytokine-mediated proliferation and differentiation: This is correct. Once activated, T-cells undergo proliferation and differentiation, aided by cytokines.

Key Takeaways:

  • The PD1/PD-L1 pathway is involved in immune regulation and inhibition, not activation.
  • T-cell activation requires interaction with APCs, co-stimulation through CD28/CD28L, and cytokine-driven differentiation.

Reference:

Immunology - T-Cell Activation
